Award.AwardTitle: Travel to Attend The 3rd Laser Ignition Conference

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: To achieve high efficiency and low emission, many practical combustion systems have resorted to combustion regimes wherein ignition is severely impeded. To overcome the difficulties associated with ignition, lasers are an attractive ignition tool for thse combustion regimes. This International Conference has been one of the premier interdisciplinary conferences where scientists with diverse backgrounds (e.g.; experts in combustion, laser physics, spectroscopy, and plasma) come together to present their highest quality research and discuss new ideas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The goal of this NSF travel funding was to encourage a new generation of graduate students interested in the laser-induced ignition of internal combustion engine and gas turbines to attend the conference. The travel awards helped to foster the development of the next advanced engine combustion by encouraging graduate students to attend, present their work, and interact with other important researchers in the field. They had the opportunity to interact with, and potentially collaborate with, researchers who are producing work of the highest quality.

In order to achieve higher fuel efficiencies, and lower fuel emissions while maintaining engine specific power densities, many practical combustion systems have resorted to advanced combustion regimes wherein ignition is severely impeded. Laser ignition has proved instrumental in unlocking the true potential of such combustion modes. This is the 4th Laser Ignition Conference (LIC) at Yokohama, Japan from 17 May 2016 to 20 May 2016 that attempted to collate the latest developments in laser and laser technologies for the feasibility of laser ignition in practical combustion systems. This International Conference has been one of the premier interdisciplinary conferences where scientists with diverse backgrounds (e.g.; experts in combustion, laser physics, spectroscopy, and plasma) come together to present their highest quality research and discuss new ideas.

Broader Impacts

The conference gave an opportunity to researchers and graduate students specializing in the area of laser & laser technologies (hardware), advanced ignition systems for stationary natural gas engines, advanced ignition systems for vehicular applications, laser ignition in aerospace applications, laser diagnostics associated with laser induced breakdown (LIBS), and alternative ignition systems. The participation of two graduate students was supported by funds of this grant.

 


Last Modified: 03/05/2017
Modified by: Seong-Young Lee
